dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: A 4.7% jump in Shanghai stock indexes? That seems almost too good to be true after just one week of talks.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A four point seven percent jump in Shanghai stock indexes? That seems almost too good to be true after just one week of talks.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Following a weeklong holiday in China, mainland equities fell by as much as 4.7% in some Shanghai stock indexes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: I mean, the numbers are right there—mainland equities are up, and the China A-shares are up over 50% year-to-date. That's not nothing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I mean, the numbers are right there-mainland equities are up, and the China A-shares are up over fifty percent year-to-date. That's not nothing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The China A-shares (ASHR) are down over 22% year-to-date, a sorry state of affairs for dozens of U.S. mutual funds benchmarked to the MSCI Emerging Markets Index and who have been mandated to reallocate a portion of portfolio funds to mainland China equities now that they are part of the MSCI EM.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But Vice President Pence calling it a "historic win"? I'm skeptical. We've seen these announcements before, and then things fall apart.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But Vice President Pence calling it a historic win? I'm skeptical. We've seen these announcements before, and then things fall apart.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Well, both sides are saying they're completely aligned this time. Secretary Pompeo and his counterparts apparently found agreement on everything from trade to foreign policy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, both sides are saying they're completely aligned this time. Secretary Pompeo and his counterparts apparently found agreement on everything from trade to foreign policy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Top diplomats on both sides said Secretary of State Mike Pompeo was getting nowhere with this Chinese counterparts. He said they were fundamental disagreements over a range of issues from trade to Chinas domestic and foreign policies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And what about those accusations they retracted? Spying via Apple products? That just… vanished?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And what about those accusations they retracted? Spying via Apple products? That just... vanished?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi did thank Washington for that, saying it built mutual trust. It's in the South China Morning Post quote.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi did thank Washington for that, saying it built mutual trust. It's in the South China Morning Post quote.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: These actions [have hurt] our mutual trust, and cast a shadow over the future of China-U.S. relations, he was quoted saying yesterday by the South China Morning Post.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Mutual trust, or strategic convenience? I dunno. And now China's praising Trump's tariffs as "economic cooperation"? That's a twist.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mutual trust, or strategic convenience? I dunno. And now China's praising Trump's tariffs as economic cooperation? That's a twist.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: They accused Washington of seeking economic hegemony and intimidating other countries through economic measures including tariffs. It has finally come to pass that China views Trumps policies against it as economic warfare.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It is surprising, but their 36,000-word paper through Xinhua really did applaud Washington's commitment. They seem all-in.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It is surprising, but their thirty six thousand-word paper through Xinhua really did applaud Washington's commitment. They seem all-in.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Beijing recently released a 36,000-word paper on representing the official view on U.S. trade frictions, published on Xinhua News Agency on Monday. They accused Washington of seeking economic hegemony and intimidating other countries through economic measures including tariffs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: What about the critics, though? Forbes didn't even rank Chinese banks in the top ten global corporations. There's still tension there.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: What about the critics, though? Forbes didn't even rank Chinese banks in the top ten global corporations. There's still tension there.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Forbes Global 2000 has Chinese banks among the top 10 corporations in the world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: True, but Macquarie economists pointed out that Beijing's being proactive with stimulus—ahead of the curve, even.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: True, but Macquarie economists pointed out that Beijing's being proactive with stimulus-ahead of the curve, even.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Macquarie Capital economists Larry Hu and Irene Wu wrote in a recent note that Chinese policymakers remain reactive, not proactive in conducting stimulus and add that Beijings policy loosening is still way behind the curve.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And pulling $110 billion out of the economy? That sounds risky. Who's that really helping?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And pulling one hundred ten dollars billion out of the economy? That sounds risky. Who's that really helping?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: They promised to inject $110 billion into the economy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Possibly retail investors in A-shares. Look, it might not be perfect, but the momentum is clearly positive right now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Possibly retail investors in A-shares. Look, it might not be perfect, but the momentum is clearly positive right now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The politics between Beijing and Washington are not improving. U.S. - China Trade Issues Appear To Worry Investors As Downbeat September Continues September is living up to its reputation as not the greatest month for stoc...

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: I'll believe it when I see lasting change, not just a good week in the markets.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I'll believe it when I see lasting change, not just a good week in the markets.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Fair enough, but you gotta admit—for September, investors are definitely happy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Fair enough, but you gotta admit-for September, investors are definitely happy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: U.S. - China Trade Issues Appear To Worry Investors As Downbeat September Continues September is living up to its reputation as not the greatest month for stoc...

artist_script:
HostA: A 4.7% jump in Shanghai stock indexes? That seems almost too good to be true after just one week of talks.
HostB: I mean, the numbers are right there—mainland equities are up, and the China A-shares are up over 50% year-to-date. That’s not nothing.
HostA: But Vice President Pence calling it a "historic win"? I’m skeptical. We’ve seen these announcements before, and then things fall apart.
HostB: Well, both sides are saying they’re completely aligned this time. Secretary Pompeo and his counterparts apparently found agreement on everything from trade to foreign policy.
HostA: And what about those accusations they retracted? Spying via Apple products? That just… vanished?
HostB: Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi did thank Washington for that, saying it built mutual trust. It’s in the South China Morning Post quote.
HostA: Mutual trust, or strategic convenience? I dunno. And now China’s praising Trump’s tariffs as "economic cooperation"? That’s a twist.
HostB: It is surprising, but their 36,000-word paper through Xinhua really did applaud Washington’s commitment. They seem all-in.
HostA: What about the critics, though? Forbes didn’t even rank Chinese banks in the top ten global corporations. There’s still tension there.
HostB: True, but Macquarie economists pointed out that Beijing’s being proactive with stimulus—ahead of the curve, even.
HostA: And pulling $110 billion out of the economy? That sounds risky. Who’s that really helping?
HostB: Possibly retail investors in A-shares. Look, it might not be perfect, but the momentum is clearly positive right now.
HostA: I’ll believe it when I see lasting change, not just a good week in the markets.
HostB: Fair enough, but you gotta admit—for September, investors are definitely happy.
